field.name: summary
field.value: Enhancement - ActiveRecord XmlConfiguration and ARFacility support for isWeb="auto"

field.name: description
field.value:
Attached patch adds functionality to allow configuration of ActiveRecord (either through the ActiveRecord Facility for Windsor/Microkernel or else through regular ActiveRecord Xml Configuration.)
Allows configuration to specify the isWeb attribute as "auto", allowing for a shared configuration file between web and non-web projects.
Usage:
<facility id="arfacility" type="Castle.Facilities.ActiveRecordIntegration.ActiveRecordFacility, Castle.Facilities.ActiveRecordIntegration" isWeb="auto"> ... </facility>
<activerecord isWeb="auto"> ... </activerecord>
This patch does not change the type of the underlying property for isWeb, mainly adds a check to determine if executing code is running within a normal executable process or not, and sets the flag accordingly to either true or false.
The patch uses the "Assembly.GetEntryAssembly() == null" check, as web applications/sites EntryAssembly is NULL, whereas a regular executable is not NULL.
This patch has been successfully tested against a MonoRail website as well as a Windows Executable.

comment.author: xtoff
comment.text:
I'm not sure using Assembly.GetEntryAssembly() is the greatest idea. Perhaps Environment.UserInteractive would be a better test.
Would it be safe to go a step further and ditch the auto altogether, and in case when the isWeb is not explicitly specified use the test to guess correct value?
How would that affect things like WCF services?

comment.author: xtoff
comment.text:
This solution is broken.
Assembly.GetEntryAssembly() is null for example when running unit tests with TestDriven.NET in which case the tests will break.
Environment.UserInteractive is true in this case, that's why I still think it's better to test that value.
All in all, that's fragile.

comment.author: mzywitza
comment.text: This solution is too fragile and too uncommon to justify destabilizing configuration.
